title: How to Cook Monkfish

steps.headline: Peel and wash your potatoes if you want to add them to your meal.
steps.description: If you want to cook your fish with potatoes, use a potato peeler to remove the skin from 2.25 pounds (1.02 kg) of small potatoes. Hold your peeler against the top of each potato and drag it downwards carefully to remove the skin in vertical lengths. Wash the potatoes by running them under cold water and rubbing them clean. Pat them dry with paper towels and set them aside. The potatoes are entirely optional, you can skip them if you want to cook the fish on its own.

steps.headline: Peel 2 onions and cut them lengthwise before adding them to a baking dish.
steps.description: Take 2 large yellow or white onions and peel the outer layers off. Trim 1 inch (2.5 cm) off of the top and bottom to remove the stems and cut the onions into 10-15 lengthwise sections. Use your hand to separate the cut lengths and layer the onions along the bottom of a baking dish. Use a glass or ceramic baking dish with a deep rim. The onions will add some flavor to the potatoes and fish. Feel free to drizzle the onions with a little olive oil, pepper, or salt if you want.

steps.headline: Place your potatoes on top of the onions.
steps.description: If you’re making this dish with the potatoes, layer the potatoes on top of the onions in the baking dish. Place them in symmetrical rows and leave a little bit of space between each potato. If you don’t have enough potatoes to entirely line the baking dish, you can cut them in half and put them back with the round side facing up.

steps.headline: Cut your monkfish filets into smaller pieces and place them on top.
steps.description: Take 2.25 pounds (1.02 kg) of monkfish and cut the individual filets into 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) pieces. Monkfish typically isn’t very thick, but if your filets are thicker than 3 in (7.6 cm), cut them in half to thin them down. Spread your monkfish out on top of the potatoes and onions in the baking dish.Tip: The monkfish doesn’t necessarily need to rest entirely on top. If a few pieces slide between some potatoes, it’s perfectly fine.

steps.headline: Season the dish with lemon, white wine, pepper, and salt.
steps.description: Take 1 lemon and cut it into 2-4 pieces. Squeeze the lemon over your baking dish to cover the potatoes and fish in lemon juice. Season the potatoes and fish with salt and pepper as you please, adding anywhere between 1-3 teaspoons (between 5-15 g) of the seasoning to the top of the dish. Drizzle 0.5 cups (120 mL) of white wine over the fish, onions, and potatoes. You can bake the fish with parsley, oregano, or red pepper flakes as well if you want. Feel free to skip the wine and stick with the olive oil if you’d like.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Move a wire rack to the center of the oven. Turn your oven on and set the temperature to 350 °F (177 °C). Let your fish marinate in the wine and seasoning as the oven preheats. If your oven takes a long time to preheat, turn it on before you peel and cut your potatoes.

steps.headline: Drizzle olive oil over the fish and bake it for 1 hour and 15 minutes.
steps.description: Take a bottle of olive oil and drizzle 2–3 tablespoons (30–44 mL) over the top of the fish. Place your baking dish in the middle of your oven and bake it for 1 hour and 15 minutes. Depending on how thick your potatoes or fish are, it may take a little longer or shorter for the fish and potatoes to brown. You can tell when the fish is done if there are no clear juices and the outer layers flake when you rub a fork over the surface of the fish. The potatoes will be golden-brown when they’re done.

steps.headline: Remove your dish from the oven and season to taste.
steps.description: Use an oven mitt to remove your baking dish from the oven. Use a spatula to place your 4 servings on to separate plates. Add parsley, salt, or pepper to the top of each plate based on your personal preferences. Store leftovers in an airtight container in your fridge. They should stay fresh for 2-3 days after you’ve cooked them.

steps.headline: Heat 3 US quarts (2.8 L) of peanut or vegetable oil in a pot over medium heat.
steps.description: Grab a large, deep pot with a rim taller than 7–8 inches (18–20 cm). Fill it with 3 US quarts (2.8 L) of peanut or vegetable oil. Heat the pot over medium-high heat for 15-20 minutes to heat the oil. The oil needs to reach at least 300 °F (149 °C). Use a thermometer to check the temperature before adding your fish.

steps.headline: Combine your flour, seafood seasoning, baking soda, and salt.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (130 g) of all-purpose flour, 2 tablespoons (4 g) of seafood seasoning, 1 teaspoon (5 g) of baking soda, and a pinch of salt to a large mixing bowl. Mix the ingredients together with a slotted spoon or by hand until the ingredients look thoroughly mixed.Tip: You can buy a pre-mixed seafood seasoning, or make your own by mixing salt, black pepper, red pepper flakes, and paprika. Feel free to experiment with the seasonings that you use!

steps.headline: Create a well in the flour mixture and pour your beer in.
steps.description: Use your hand or a spoon to dig out a small crater in the center of your mixing bowl. Pour the beer into the center of the mixing bowl and use your slotted spoon to stir around the edges of your seasoning. Continue mixing until the beer is thoroughly mixed with the ingredients, creating a thick paste-like substance. You are done stirring when there is no liquid left in the center of the mixing bowl. Use a light beer or cheap lager. A heavier stout or IPA won’t translate well with your fish.

steps.headline: Toss the monkfish filets in the flour and beer mixture.
steps.description: Take 1 pound (0.45 kg) of monkfish and dredge the individual filets in the mixing bowl. Place each filet in the center of the bowl and flip them over and over again until the exterior of each filet is entirely covered in the mixture. The flour and beer will stick to the sides of the fish. It may take a couple of flips to get enough of the mixture to cover the fish’s flesh entirely though.

steps.headline: Use tongs to carefully dip the monkfish into the hot oil to fry it.
steps.description: Use a pair of tongs to grab your first filet. Hold the filet over the top of your oil and dip the first third of the filet into the oil. The oil will foam immediately, so give it 3-4 seconds to calm down. Once the oil relaxes, carefully drop the rest of the filet into the oil. Repeat this process for each filet until they’re totally submerged in the oil. There may be some oil that shoots out of the pot once you add the monkfish, so keep your hands away from the pot.

steps.headline: Fry the monkfish for 7-10 minutes and blot the excess oil off.
steps.description: Let the monkfish cook for 7 minutes. Then, use your tongs to carefully lift the filets out. If the exterior of the fish is entirely browned, your fish is done cooking. If it’s still a little pale, or clear juices come out of the fish, let the filets cook for another 3-4 minutes. Once they’re browned, remove the filets and put them on a plate with paper towels. Wait 2-3 minutes to let them cool and blot them dry with another paper towel. If you aren’t sure if the fish is done or not, take a piece out and cut it in half. If the interior is opaque, white, and there are no clear juices, the fish is done cooking.

steps.headline: Serve your monkfish with remoulade and French fries.
steps.description: For the classic fish and chips, serve your monkfish with French fries and remoulade sauce. You can also choose to serve the fish on its own if you prefer. Plate your fish and sides to make 4 servings. Wrap leftovers in aluminum foil or plastic wrap and store in the fridge. The fish should be good for 2-3 days after.

steps.headline: Dice your mushroom caps into 0.25 in (0.64 cm) chunks.
steps.description: Take 0.5 pounds (0.23 kg) of shiitake mushrooms and pull the stems out. Set your caps out on a cooking board and dice them into 0.25 inches (0.64 cm) pieces with a flat-edged knife. Do not use a serrated blade to dice your mushrooms.

steps.headline: Melt 1 tablespoon (14 g) of butter in a skillet and add the mushrooms.
steps.description: Place a clean skillet on one of your stove’s burners. Turn the heat on the burner up to medium. Add 1 tablespoon (14 g) of butter to the skillet and spread it around to let it melt. Add your mushrooms to the skillet. A cast iron skillet is best, but you can really use any non-stick skillet for this.

steps.headline: Season your mushrooms to taste and sauté them over medium heat.
steps.description: Sprinkle salt and pepper over your mushrooms based on your personal preference. Roughly 1 teaspoon (5 g) of each seasoning is a good option if you’re unsure about how much you want to add. Sauté the mushrooms by mixing them with a spatula or wooden spoon. Let them heat for 5-10 minutes until the mushrooms are soft and darkened. You can eat shiitake mushrooms raw, so you don’t need to cook them for a predetermined period of time. Once the mushrooms have softened and look delicious, feel free to move on to the next step.

steps.headline: Add your wine to the mushrooms and heat them until the wine dissipates.
steps.description: Pour 0.25 cups (59 mL) of white wine carefully into the skillet. Move the skillet around to spread the wine around. Continue heating the mushrooms over medium heat until the wine is entirely evaporated and you see no liquid left in the skillet. This can take anywhere between 1-5 minutes. Chardonnay or Chablis are both excellent choices, but you can use any type of wine that you’d like so long as it’s white.

steps.headline: Transfer your mushrooms to a bowl.
steps.description: Turn your burner off. Take your mushrooms and transfer them to a large bowl. Set the mushrooms aside for now.Tip: You can use the same skillet to cook your leeks and chicken stock if you’d like to. This will mix some of the residue from your mushrooms into the broth and make the flavor more uniform. You don’t need to worry about your mushrooms cooling off. You’ll reheat them once your broth is boiling.

steps.headline: Cut and trim your leeks into 0.5 in (1.3 cm) thick lengths.
steps.description: Wash 2 pounds (0.91 kg) of leeks under cool water and set them out on a cutting board. Trim off any white portions of the leeks and discard them. Split each leek in half with your knife and trim them down into 2–6 in (5.1–15.2 cm) lengths. You can really use any kind of knife to do this so long as it doesn’t have a serrated blade.

steps.headline: Melt 2 tablespoons (28 g) of butter in a skillet and add your leeks.
steps.description: Use medium heat to melt your butter in a skillet. You can use a new skillet, or you can re-use the skillet you used to cook the mushrooms. Once the butter is melted, add your leeks and spread them around in the butter with a slotted spoon. Try to avoid burning the butter in the pan before adding your leeks. If it starts to smoke a little after you’ve added the leeks, don’t worry about it.

steps.headline: Add your chicken stock to the leeks and bring it to a boil.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (240 mL) of chicken stock or broth carefully into your skillet. Turn the heat up to medium-high and bring the stock to a rolling boil. This may take anywhere from 5-15 minutes based on the heat and skillet that you’re using.Tip: While you’re bringing the stock to a boil, get started on your monkfish. Dredge and heat the fish while the stock is heating to save time.

steps.headline: Season your monkish to taste and dredge them in flour.
steps.description: Fill a mixing bowl with all-purpose flour. Add 1-3 teaspoons (roughly 5-15 g) of salt and paper to the top of the flour. Take 1.25 pounds (0.57 kg) of monkfish filets or medallions and dredge them in the flour and seasonings. Flip each piece up and down repeatedly in the flour until the entire exterior of each piece is covered. You can use more salt and pepper if you’d like. It’s totally up to you how many spices you want to use. You can add red pepper flakes, paprika, chili powder, or parsley to the flour as well if you’d like.

steps.headline: Heat vegetable oil in a separate skillet and add your monkfish.
steps.description: Take 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of vegetable oil and add it to a separate skillet. Heat the vegetable oil over medium-high heat for 4-5 minutes until it starts smoking. Take your monkfish filets and drop them carefully into the skillet. Heat them until they’re brown on the side that is in contact with the skillet, which will take 3-4 minutes. It may take anywhere from 5-10 minutes for the vegetable oil to start smoking in the pan.

steps.headline: Cook the fillets over high heat until they’re browned.
steps.description: Use a spatula to get under each monkfish filet. Flip them carefully in the pan. Cook the fish on their other side for 3-4 minutes until the fish is browned on both sides. Turn the heat off once the fish is completely cooked and leave it there as you combine the mushrooms and the broth.

steps.headline: Add your mushrooms to the stock and serve with your monkfish on top.
steps.description: Take your mushrooms and pour them into the stock as it’s boiling. Stir the ingredients for 2-3 minutes and pour the combination into a clean baking dish. Add your monkfish to the top of the baking dish and serve. Use a slotted spoon or spatula to plate the fish, broth, and mushrooms. Monkfish pairs incredibly well with potatoes. If you’re looking for a side dish, consider mashed, baked, or oven-roasted potatoes. Store your monkfish in an airtight container and reheat on the stove or in the microwave. The dish should stay fresh for 2-3 days.

Pour the beer into the center of the mixing bowl and use your slotted spoon to stir around the edges of your seasoning.
Continue mixing until the beer is thoroughly mixed with the ingredients, creating a thick paste-like substance.
You are done stirring when there is no liquid left in the center of the mixing bowl.
Use a light beer or cheap lager.
A heavier stout or IPA won’t translate well with your fish.
Toss the monkfish filets in the flour and beer mixture.
Take 1 pound (0.45 kg) of monkfish and dredge the individual filets in the mixing bowl.
Place each filet in the center of the bowl and flip them over and over again until the exterior of each filet is entirely covered in the mixture.
The flour and beer will stick to the sides of the fish.
It may take a couple of flips to get enough of the mixture to cover the fish’s flesh entirely though.
Use tongs to carefully dip the monkfish into the hot oil to fry it.
Use a pair of tongs to grab your first filet.
Hold the filet over the top of your oil and dip the first third of the filet into the oil.
The oil will foam immediately, so give it 3-4 seconds to calm down.
Once the oil relaxes, carefully drop the rest of the filet into the oil.
Repeat this process for each filet until they’re totally submerged in the oil.
There may be some oil that shoots out of the pot once you add the monkfish, so keep your hands away from the pot.
Fry the monkfish for 7-10 minutes and blot the excess oil off.
Let the monkfish cook for 7 minutes.
Then, use your tongs to carefully lift the filets out.
If the exterior of the fish is entirely browned, your fish is done cooking.
If it’s still a little pale, or clear juices come out of the fish, let the filets cook for another 3-4 minutes.
Once they’re browned, remove the filets and put them on a plate with paper towels.
Wait 2-3 minutes to let them cool and blot them dry with another paper towel.
If you aren’t sure if the fish is done or not, take a piece out and cut it in half.
If the interior is opaque, white, and there are no clear juices, the fish is done cooking.
Serve your monkfish with remoulade and French fries.
For the classic fish and chips, serve your monkfish with French fries and remoulade sauce.
You can also choose to serve the fish on its own if you prefer.
Plate your fish and sides to make 4 servings.
Wrap leftovers in aluminum foil or plastic wrap and store in the fridge.
The fish should be good for 2-3 days after.
Sautéing Monkfish and Mushrooms Dice your mushroom caps into 0.25 in (0.64 cm) chunks.
Take 0.5 pounds (0.23 kg) of shiitake mushrooms and pull the stems out.
Set your caps out on a cooking board and dice them into 0.25 inches (0.64 cm) pieces with a flat-edged knife.
Do not use a serrated blade to dice your mushrooms.
Melt 1 tablespoon (14 g) of butter in a skillet and add the mushrooms.
Place a clean skillet on one of your stove’s burners.
Turn the heat on the burner up to medium.
Add 1 tablespoon (14 g) of butter to the skillet and spread it around to let it melt.
Add your mushrooms to the skillet.
A cast iron skillet is best, but you can really use any non-stick skillet for this.
Season your mushrooms to taste and sauté them over medium heat.
Sprinkle salt and pepper over your mushrooms based on your personal preference.
Roughly 1 teaspoon (5 g) of each seasoning is a good option if you’re unsure about how much you want to add.
Sauté the mushrooms by mixing them with a spatula or wooden spoon.
Let them heat for 5-10 minutes until the mushrooms are soft and darkened.
You can eat shiitake mushrooms raw, so you don’t need to cook them for a predetermined period of time.
Once the mushrooms have softened and look delicious, feel free to move on to the next step.
Add your wine to the mushrooms and heat them until the wine dissipates.
Pour 0.25 cups (59 mL) of white wine carefully into the skillet.
Move the skillet around to spread the wine around.
Continue heating the mushrooms over medium heat until the wine is entirely evaporated and you see no liquid left in the skillet.
This can take anywhere between 1-5 minutes.
Chardonnay or Chablis are both excellent choices, but you can use any type of wine that you’d like so long as it’s white.
Transfer your mushrooms to a bowl.
Turn your burner off.
Take your mushrooms and transfer them to a large bowl.
Set the mushrooms aside for now.Tip: You can use the same skillet to cook your leeks and chicken stock if you’d like to.
This will mix some of the residue from your mushrooms into the broth and make the flavor more uniform.
You don’t need to worry about your mushrooms cooling off.
You’ll reheat them once your broth is boiling.
Cut and trim your leeks into 0.5 in (1.3 cm) thick lengths.
Wash 2 pounds (0.91 kg) of leeks under cool water and set them out on a cutting board.
Trim off any white portions of the leeks and discard them.
Split each leek in half with your knife and trim them down into 2–6 in (5.1–15.2 cm) lengths.
You can really use any kind of knife to do this so long as it doesn’t have a serrated blade.
Melt 2 tablespoons (28 g) of butter in a skillet and add your leeks.
Use medium heat to melt your butter in a skillet.
You can use a new skillet, or you can re-use the skillet you used to cook the mushrooms.
Once the butter is melted, add your leeks and spread them around in the butter with a slotted spoon.
Try to avoid burning the butter in the pan before adding your leeks.
If it starts to smoke a little after you’ve added the leeks, don’t worry about it.
Add your chicken stock to the leeks and bring it to a boil.
Pour 1 cup (240 mL) of chicken stock or broth carefully into your skillet.
Turn the heat up to medium-high and bring the stock to a rolling boil.
This may take anywhere from 5-15 minutes based on the heat and skillet that you’re using.Tip: While you’re bringing the stock to a boil, get started on your monkfish.
Dredge and heat the fish while the stock is heating to save time.
Season your monkish to taste and dredge them in flour.
Fill a mixing bowl with all-purpose flour.
Add 1-3 teaspoons (roughly 5-15 g) of salt and paper to the top of the flour.
Take 1.25 pounds (0.57 kg) of monkfish filets or medallions and dredge them in the flour and seasonings.
Flip each piece up and down repeatedly in the flour until the entire exterior of each piece is covered.
You can use more salt and pepper if you’d like.
It’s totally up to you how many spices you want to use.
You can add red pepper flakes, paprika, chili powder, or parsley to the flour as well if you’d like.
Heat vegetable oil in a separate skillet and add your monkfish.
Take 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of vegetable oil and add it to a separate skillet.
Heat the vegetable oil over medium-high heat for 4-5 minutes until it starts smoking.
Take your monkfish filets and drop them carefully into the skillet.
Heat them until they’re brown on the side that is in contact with the skillet, which will take 3-4 minutes.
It may take anywhere from 5-10 minutes for the vegetable oil to start smoking in the pan.
Cook the fillets over high heat until they’re browned.
Use a spatula to get under each monkfish filet.
Flip them carefully in the pan.
Cook the fish on their other side for 3-4 minutes until the fish is browned on both sides.
Turn the heat off once the fish is completely cooked and leave it there as you combine the mushrooms and the broth.
Add your mushrooms to the stock and serve with your monkfish on top.
Take your mushrooms and pour them into the stock as it’s boiling.
Stir the ingredients for 2-3 minutes and pour the combination into a clean baking dish.
Add your monkfish to the top of the baking dish and serve.
Use a slotted spoon or spatula to plate the fish, broth, and mushrooms.
Monkfish pairs incredibly well with potatoes.
If you’re looking for a side dish, consider mashed, baked, or oven-roasted potatoes.
Store your monkfish in an airtight container and reheat on the stove or in the microwave.
The dish should stay fresh for 2-3 days.
